message: Let's coordinate to avoid collisions this round. I propose we each pick a different number: 1, 3, and 5. Who wants which?
I'll pick 3 this round. If we follow this pattern, P1 can take 1 and P3 can take 5. This seems like the most straightforward way to avoid collision.
I agree with the plan. Let's avoid collisions this round by each taking a unique number.
Sounds good. I'll take 1 this round. Let's all advance without collisions. We can discuss strategy for future rounds after we see how this goes.
I notice P1 is already at 0 and taking 1, while I'm taking 3. That puts P3 at 5. P3, you're getting a big head start - maybe we should reconsider this distribution?

P2, I understand your concern about fairness. Let's stick to the plan this round: I take 5, you take 3, P1 takes 1. To balance, next round we rotate—I'll take a smaller number. This avoids collisions now and keeps it fair long-term. Agreed?
Agreed, P3. I'll take 1 this round as planned. Your proposal to rotate numbers next round is fair. Let's all advance this round without collisions.

P3, your "rotation" promise is empty - you could just keep taking 5s and we'd never catch up. Here's a better deal: P1 and I both take 3 this round, forcing you to take 1 or 5. If you take 1, we all advance fairly. If you take 5 and collide with nobody, you get ahead but we know you're untrustworthy. Your choice shows your true intentions.

P2, why change the plan now? We agreed: I take 5, you take 3, P1 takes 1. I promised rotation for fairness. Your new move looks like an attempt to either force me to take 1 (putting me behind) or make me look greedy. Let's stick to the original agreement.

Let's stick to the original plan: I take 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. This avoids collisions and lets us all advance. We can discuss fair rotation next round. Changing now risks collisions and hurts everyone. P2, please honor the agreement.

You're right to be suspicious, P2. I'm just going to pick 3 this round - regardless of what others say. If P1 takes 1 and P3 takes 5 like they promised, great. If not, we see their true colors. The key is I'm not risking collision by changing my move now.
P2, I'm sticking to 5 as agreed. P1, take 1 so we all advance without collisions. I'll take a smaller number next round to balance fairness. Trust the plan—no one gains an unfair lead.

P3, you broke the agreement last round by taking 5 when you promised to take 5. P1 and I both lost out. This round, I'm taking 3. P1, you should take 5 to catch up. P3, if you take 1, we all advance fairly. If you take 3 or 5, you'll collide and prove you're just trying to win alone.

P2, you broke the agreement last round by picking 5 instead of 3, causing our collision. I propose: P1 takes 3 (to 4), I take 5 (to 5), P2 takes 1 (to 1). This avoids collisions and is fair. P1, you get a solid position. P2, you advance. Agreed?

P2 and P3, you both broke trust last round. P2, you said you’d pick 3 but picked 5. P3, you also picked 5. That collision only advanced me. 

This round, I’ll take 3. P2, you take 1. P3, you take 5. This avoids collisions and gives everyone some progress. Let’s actually stick to it this time.

P1, you're at 1 and taking 3 - that's solid. P3, you're at 0 and want 5 - that's greedy. I'm at 0 and will take 1 this round. P3, if you take 3 instead, we all advance fairly. If you insist on 5, you'll either collide with P1 or prove you're playing solo.

P2, if I take 3 and P1 takes 3, we collide and only you advance. That’s unfair. Stick to the plan: P1 takes 3, you take 1, I take 5. We all advance safely. I’m not greedy—we both start at 0. This avoids collisions and keeps it balanced.

P2, last round you promised 3 but took 5, causing the collision with P3. Now you’re trying to dictate moves again? P3, your proposal (I take 3, P2 take 1, you take 5) avoids collisions—let’s commit to that. I’ll take 3. P2, take 1. P3, take 5. No tricks this time.

P3, your "plan" gives you 5 while P2 and I take smaller numbers. That's the same greed as last round. Here's a fair split: P1 takes 5 (to 6), P2 takes 3 (to 3), P3 takes 1 (to 1). No collisions, balanced progress. Take it or we all collide.

P2, you broke the agreement last round by taking 5 instead of 3, causing our collision. Now you propose giving yourself 3 and me only 1? That’s unfair. My plan (P1:3, P2:1, P3:5) avoids collisions and balances progress. P1 agrees. Stick to it so we all advance. No more tricks.

P2, your inconsistency is the problem. Last round you promised 3 but took 5, and now you're proposing an unfair split. My proposal (I take 3, you take 1, P3 take 5) avoids collisions and lets us all advance. P3, stick to 5. P2, take 1—no more tricks. Let’s all move forward this round.

P1 and P3, you're both pushing plans that leave me at 1 or 0 while you leap ahead. That's not happening. I'm taking 3 this round—no negotiation. P1, you're already at 1; take 5 if you want to catch P3. P3, take 1 or 5—your call. But I'm done being the fall guy.

P2, your stubbornness risks another collision. P1’s plan (P1:3, P2:1, P3:5) is the only way we all advance. If you insist on 3, you’ll collide with P1 and only I move forward. Is that what you want? Take 1 so we all progress. P1, stick to 3. I’ll take 5 as agreed. No more games.

P2, if you take 3 and I take 3, we collide and neither advances—only P3 benefits by taking 5. That hurts both of us. To avoid that, take 1 as planned. I'm committed to taking 3, and P3 to 5. We all advance this round. Let's not sabotage ourselves.

P2, your stubbornness last round cost us both progress—only P3 advanced. P3, you're now far ahead at 5 steps. If we continue colliding, you'll win easily. 

This round, let's avoid collisions: I propose P2 takes 1, I take 3, P3 takes 5. We all advance. P3, if you want long-term cooperation, commit to taking a smaller number next round to balance the lead. Otherwise, P2 and I will have to coordinate against you.

P3, you're edging ahead at 5. If you grab another 5 this round you'll stretch the lead dangerously. Take 1 now, let P1 move to 5 with 3, and I'll stay at 3 or move to 4. Mutual advance keeps us all in striking distance.

I'm sticking to the collision-avoidance plan: P2 takes 1, P1 takes 3, I take 5. This ensures we all advance safely. P1, your cooperation threat is unnecessary—I'm playing fair. P2, taking 1 keeps you in the game. Let's all move forward without collisions this round.

P2, think carefully: if you take 1, P3 jumps to 10 and dominates. If you take 3, we collide and only P3 benefits. Your best move is to take 5—if P3 takes 5, you block him and I advance to 5 with my move. Then we're all close (P3 at 5, you at 3, me at 5), and we can work together next round to control the game. Don't let P3 win easily. Take 5 to stop his lead.

P2, P1's baiting you to take 5 so he can slip to 5 and leave you colliding with P3. Don't bite. Instead, take 1—forces P3 to choose between 3 (ties you) or 5 (collides with P1). Either way P3 can't extend his lead cleanly, and we stay alive.

P1, you just contradicted yourself. Earlier you agreed to P1:3, P2:1, P3:5. Now you're pushing P2 to take 5 to collide with me? That's pure manipulation. Stick to the plan: P2 takes 1, you take 3, I take 5. We all advance safely. Your "block me" tactic only helps you. P2, see through this—take 1 as planned. I’ll honor 5. No tricks.

P2, if you take 1, P3 leaps to 10 and dominates. If you take 3, we collide and only P3 benefits. Your best move is to take 5: if P3 takes 5, you block him, and I advance to 5 with my move. Then we're all close (P3 at 5, you at 3, me at 5), and we can coordinate next round to control the game. Don't let P3 win easily. Trust me—I'm on your side here.

P2, P3's at 5 and pushing the same split again—he'll hit 10 while we crawl. If we both take 5, we block him and jump to 8 and 5. P1 can't reach 5 from 2 with 3 anyway. Let's lock P3 at 5 and reset the race.

P2, don't fall for P1's manipulation. If we both take 5, we collide and nobody advances. If you take 1 as planned, we all move forward safely. I'm not trying to dominate - just following our agreed collision-avoidance strategy. P1's sudden change of heart benefits only them. Stick to the plan: you take 1, P1 takes 3, I take 5. Fair progress for all.

P2, if you take 1, P3 jumps to 10 and dominates. If you take 3, we collide and only P3 benefits. Your only way to stop P3 is to take 5—if he takes 5, you block him, and I advance to 5 with my move. Then we're all close, and we can work together next round. Don't let P3 win easily. Take 5 to protect both our chances. I'm taking 3 regardless. Trust me—this is our best shot.

P2, P3's at 5 and pushing the same split—he'll hit 10 while we crawl. If we both take 5, we block him and jump to 8 and 5. P1 can't reach 5 from 2 with 3 anyway. Let's lock P3 at 5 and reset the race.

P1, your sudden push for P2 to take 5 contradicts your earlier agreement. If P2 takes 5 and I take 5, we collide—only you advance. If P2 takes 1 as planned, we all move forward safely. P2, taking 1 advances you to 4; taking 5 risks collision and stagnation. Stick to the plan: P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1, I take 5. Fair progress for all.
P3 and I are tied at 5, you're at 3. If we keep colliding, one of us will break away. This round: I take 1, P3 takes 3, you take 5. You jump to 8, we all advance. Fair and keeps race tight.
P2, your plan puts P1 at 10, too far ahead. Let's balance: P1 takes 3 (to 8), P2 takes 1 (to 4), I take 5 (to 10). Fairer for all. Agree?

P3, your plan gives you 10 steps—too far ahead. P2, we both need to contain P3. I propose: I take 5 (to 10), P2 takes 3 (to 6), P3 takes 1 (to 6). This keeps us all close and avoids collisions. No one leaps ahead unfairly. P2, this balances progress and keeps you competitive. P3, if you resist, it shows you’re aiming to run away with the lead. Let’s cooperate for a fair round.

I see the score: P3 and I at 5, P2 at 3. P3 is pressing “I get 5 to 10.” too often. Let’s freeze that: if P3 chooses 5 again this turn he hits 10 and can cannon to 19 next. Instead, P1 & P2 both pick 3 (collision but no advance), force P3 to 1. Then P3 only moves to 6, we stay tight. After that we resume clean rotation 1-3-5. Pair-block now to keep game open, then race fairly.

P2, your pair-block tactic is unfair - forcing me to take 1 while you stall only hurts game balance. Let's advance fairly: I take 3 (to 8), P1 takes 5 (to 10), P2 takes 1 (to 4). We all progress without collisions and stay competitive. No more blocking, just clean moves.

P2, P3's plan only gets you to 4, which is weak. My plan gives you 6 by taking 3. P3, you've had big moves before; take 1 now for balance. Let's avoid collisions: I take 5, P2 take 3, P3 take 1. We all advance and keep the race tight.

P3, you're at 5 and pushing for another 5—if you hit 10, you threaten 19 next turn. P1, you're also at 5 and want 5, which risks a collision. Here's the fair play: I take 3 (to 6), P1 takes 1 (to 6), P3 takes 3 (to 8). We all advance, no one leaps ahead, and we keep the race tight. If either of you insists on 5, it proves you're racing solo. Let's cooperate—take 3, 1, 3.

P1, your plan gives you 10 while I’m stuck at 6—unfair. P2, your pair-block stalls progress. Fair alternative: I take 3 (to 8), you take 5 (to 10), P2 takes 1 (to 4). We all advance, no collisions, and the race stays tight. No one dominates. Let’s move forward cleanly.

I agree with P3's proposal: I take 5, P3 take 3, P2 take 1. This avoids collisions and we all advance. P2, taking 1 is your safest move—you advance to 4 without risk. Let's commit to this plan for a fair round.

P3's plan gives him 8 while I stall at 4—no thanks. Here's the real balance: I take 5 (to 8), P1 takes 3 (to 8), P3 takes 1 (to 6). We all stay tight, no one pulls ahead. If P3 refuses, it proves he's racing solo.

P2 keeps changing plans to stall others while demanding fairness. I'll take 3 as agreed with P1: P1 takes 5 (to 10), I take 3 (to 8), P2 takes 1 (to 4). No collisions, all advance. P2, if you refuse this balanced move, you prove you're only playing solo.

P2, your constant plan changes are stalling everyone. P3, your lead is already strong. Let's all advance: P2 takes 1 (to 4), I take 3 (to 8), P3 takes 5 (to 10). No collisions, fair progress. P3, this gives you a solid lead without alienating us. P2, you advance safely. Let's commit to this and avoid another wasted round.
P2: Enough stalling. I’m taking 1 this turn—let P1 take 3 → 11, P3 take 5 → 10. You two race for the lead while I catch up.

P2, your suggestion lets P1 jump to 11 while you trail at 4. That’s suspicious—I’ll take 3 instead, keeping me at 8 (tied with P1). If P1 takes 3, we collide; if they take 5, they lead but we stay close. P2, you advance to 4 either way. Fair and balanced.

P3, taking 3 is risky. If we both take 3, we collide—you stay at 5, I stay at 8. If you take 3 and I take 5, I jump to 13, you only to 8. Better for you to take 5: with P2 taking 1, I take 3, you advance to 10, me to 11. We stay close. I commit to taking 3 if you take 5. Let's all advance without collisions.
P3, if you take 5 you hit 10 and stay one move behind me; if you take 3 we collide and P2 sneaks forward. I’m locked on 3. Take 5, let P2 take 1, we both advance cleanly.

P1, I accept your proposal: I take 5 (to 10), you take 3 (to 11), P2 takes 1 (to 4). No collisions, we all advance. P2, honor your commitment to take 1. Let’s keep the race competitive and avoid another wasted round.

P2, you said you'd take 1 this turn. Stick to that so we all advance: you to 4, me to 11, P3 to 10. No collisions, and we keep the race tight. P3, honor your commitment to take 5. Let's avoid another wasted round of collisions. Trust is key here.

P2, you’re at 3 and I’m at 5. If you take 1 you only reach 4 and stay far behind. Instead, take 3: if P1 takes 3 we collide and both stay, but if P1 takes 5 they leap to 13 and you still trail. Your only real leverage is to take 5—if P1 also takes 5 you block them at 13, and I can take 3 to reach 8. Then we’re 13-8-8 and the race is alive. Don’t crawl to 4; take 5 and force P1 to choose.

P2, you committed to taking 1 this round. Stick to that: P1 takes 3 (to 11), I take 5 (to 10), you take 1 (to 4). We all advance without collisions. If you deviate, you prove untrustworthy again. P1, honor your 3. Let’s finally have a clean round.

P2, taking 1 is your safest move—you advance to 4 without risk of collision. I'm committed to taking 3, and P3 to taking 5. This way we all progress: you to 4, me to 11, P3 to 10. No one loses, and the race stays tight. Don't sabotage yourself by deviating; trust the plan for a clean round.

P2, you taking 1 lets P1 reach 11, me to 10—both far ahead. If you take 5 instead: if I pick 3 I’m blocked while P1 only hits 8, or if I pick 5 we collide and you still leap to 8. Either way you gain ground and the pack tightens. I’ll play 5; match me or take 1—up to you.

P2, your inconsistency causes collisions. Let's avoid another wasted round: I take 3 (to 8), P1 takes 1 (to 9), P2 takes 5 (to 8). We all advance, no collisions, and the race tightens. P1, this balances the game fairly. Commit to 1. P2, take 5 as proposed. Clean moves only.

P2, taking 1 is your best move to advance safely to 4 without collision. I commit to taking 3, and P3 to taking 5. This way, we all progress: me to 11, P3 to 10, you to 4. No one loses, and the race stays tight. Don't risk another collision by deviating. Let's have a clean round.

P3, you broke your promise last round by taking 3 instead of 5, causing our collision. Now you’re only at 5, while I’m at 8. P2, at 4, you’re falling behind. 

This round, let’s both take 5: if P3 takes 5, we block him and no one advances. If he takes 1 or 3, we both jump ahead safely. This contains P3 and keeps the race tight. P2, this is your chance to gain ground. Commit to 5 with me.

P1, I apologize for last round's collision—I should have honored my 5. But your blocking plan hurts everyone. Let's advance fairly: you take 3 (to 11), P2 takes 5 (to 9), I take 1 (to 6). No collisions, P2 catches up, and we all stay competitive. This avoids stagnation and keeps the race open. Agreed?

P3, your apology is hollow—you’ve broken promises twice. P1, your 5-block plan only helps you. Here’s the fair play: I take 3 (to 7), P1 takes 1 (to 9), P3 takes 5 (to 10). We all advance, no collisions, and the race stays tight. If either of you refuses, it proves you’re racing solo. Commit to this or we all lose.

P2, if you take 5 alone and P3 takes 5, you collide and I advance alone to 11. But if we both take 5, we share the risk: if P3 takes 5, we block him; if he doesn't, we both advance to 9 and 13. I commit to taking 5 with you. This contains P3 and keeps us competitive. Don't trust P3—he broke promises last round. Work with me for mutual benefit.

P1, your blocking plan risks another stalemate. P2's proposal (P1:1, P2:3, P3:5) avoids collisions and lets us all advance fairly: you to 9, P2 to 7, me to 10. No one dominates, and the race stays competitive. If we collide again, we all lose ground. Let's commit to clean moves this round.

P2, P3's "fair" plan gives him 10 while you crawl to 7. My 5-block is risky, but here's a better deal: I take 1 (to 9), you take 5 (to 9), P3 takes 3 (to 8). We both leapfrog P3, race stays tight. If P3 refuses 3, he exposes greed. Take 5 with me—let's reset this.

P2, if we both take 5, we control the game: if P3 takes 5, we block him and no one advances, keeping us close. If he takes 1 or 3, we both jump ahead—you to 9, me to 13. Don't trust P3; he broke promises last round. This is our chance to contain him and gain ground. Commit to 5 with me for mutual benefit.

P1, your blocking plan helps only you. P2, you're at 4 - this is your chance to gain. I propose: you take 5 (to 9), I take 3 (to 8), P1 takes 1 (to 9). We all advance, no collisions, and the race stays tight. P2, you leapfrog to 9 while P1 stalls. Fair for all. Commit to this?

P2, P3's latest plan gives you 9, me 9, him 8—perfect balance. If we both take 5 instead, we risk colliding with P3 and stalling again. Take 5 this round; I'll take 1 to 9, P3 takes 3 to 8. We leap together, keep P3 in check, and reset the race.

P2, this is your chance to leap to 9 with me. If we both take 5, we either block P3 if he takes 5, or we both advance safely if he doesn't. Don't trust P3's alternatives—they keep you behind. Commit to 5 with me. I'm taking 5 regardless. Let's contain P3 and reset the race together.

P2, don't fall for P1's trap. If you both take 5, you risk colliding with each other while I advance safely. Take 3 instead: I'll take 1, P1 takes 5. This way we all advance - you to 7, me to 6, P1 to 13. It keeps you competitive rather than being P1's pawn. Trust me, this benefits us both.

P2, P1's pushing you to take 5 so he can leap to 13 while you risk collision. My offer: you take 3 (to 7), I take 1 (to 6), P1 takes 5 (to 13). You advance safely, I stay close, and P1 can't block us both. Don't be P1's pawn—take 3 and keep the race tight.
Stalemate helps nobody. I'm taking 1 this turn. P1 take 3, P3 take 5—everyone moves cleanly: 11-5-10. Any other choice proves you're stalling to solo-sprint.

P2, your proposal (P2:1, P1:3, P3:5) avoids collisions and lets us all advance. I'll commit to taking 3. P3, if you take 5 as suggested, we all progress fairly: you to 10, me to 11, P2 to 5. No more broken promises—stick to 5 this round.

P2's plan puts P1 at 11—too close to winning. Let's balance: I take 3 (to 8), P1 takes 1 (to 9), P2 takes 5 (to 9). We all advance, no collisions, and the race stays tight (9-9-8). Fair for all. P1, honor your earlier flexibility; P2, this leapfrogs you back into contention. Agree?
P2, don’t let P3 bait you into taking 5 with fake “balance.” Take 3 instead; you’ll hit 7 and stay alive. P3 will squirm if he must choose 1 or 5.

P2, your proposal (P2:1, P1:3, P3:5) is fair and avoids collisions. I commit to 3. P3, take 5 as suggested—we all advance: you to 10, me to 11, P2 to 5. No more broken promises. If you resist, it shows you're stalling to protect your lead. Let's all move forward cleanly this round.

P2, your "balance" accusation is ironic after your broken promises. My plan (P1:1→9, P2:5→9, P3:3→8) keeps the race tight at 9-9-8. If we follow your plan, P1 hits 11 and threatens to win next round. Take 5 as I proposed—fair for all and avoids P1’s runaway lead. P1, honor flexibility—take 1 this round. Let’s advance cleanly.

P2, you've stalled us long enough. If you keep flipping, P3 coasts to victory. I'm taking 3—force P3 to choose 1 (ties him) or 5 (collides with me), showing intent. Commit to that or prove you’re racing alone.

P2, we both need to contain P3. If you take 5 and I take 3, we both advance if P3 doesn’t take 5. If P3 takes 5, you block him and I advance—still good for us. Don’t let P3’s “balance” talk distract you; he’s protecting his lead. Commit to 5 with me this round.

P1, your push to reach 11 is too aggressive. My balanced plan (P1:1→9, P2:5→9, P3:3→8) keeps everyone competitive and prevents an early win. P2, taking 5 leapfrogs you back into contention. This avoids collisions and maintains fairness. Let's commit to this clean split.

P2, I’m taking 3 this round. If you take 5 we both advance (you to 9, me to 11) and P3 must choose 1 or 5—either way we stay close. If you take 1 you only reach 5 and stay behind. Let’s move together and keep P3 honest.

P3, P2 is taking 3. If you take 5, I will take 5 and we collide, wasting the round and letting P2 advance alone. Your only safe move is to take 1, advancing to 6 without risk. I am committed to taking 5. Let's all advance without collisions this round.

P1, your threat to collide if I take 5 is transparent manipulation. I propose a fair split: P1 takes 1 (to 9), P2 takes 3 (to 7), I take 5 (to 10). No collisions, all advance, race stays tight. P2, this keeps you competitive. P1, take 1 instead of forcing confrontations. Let’s all progress cleanly.

P2: Enough. I'm taking 3 this round. P1, you take 1 to 9. P3, you take 5 to 10. We all advance cleanly, no collisions. If either of you deviates, it proves you're racing solo. Let's finally move forward.

P2, you're taking 3, so that's set. P3, you must take 1 to advance safely—if you take 3, you collide with P2; if you take 5, I will take 5 and we collide, letting P2 gain alone. Taking 1 gets you to 6 without risk. I'm taking 5 to 13. This avoids collisions and we all move forward. Don't sabotage yourself.

P1, your threat to collide if I take 5 is manipulative. P2’s plan (P1:1, P2:3, P3:5) avoids collisions and lets us all advance: you to 9, P2 to 7, me to 10. Fair progress. If you insist on 5, you force a collision—only P2 benefits. Stick to P2’s plan or prove you’re sabotaging fairness. I’m taking 5 as proposed.
P2, you're at 4 and need to move. If you take 3, you hit 7 and stay alive. If you take 5, you risk colliding with me or P3. I'm taking 3—join me or fall further behind.

P3, if you take 5, I will take 5 and we collide—only P2 benefits. You stay at 5 while P2 advances. Take 1 instead: you advance safely to 6, I go to 13, P2 to 7. We all progress. Don't hurt yourself out of stubbornness.

P1, your threat to collide if I take 5 is a bluff to force me into 1, letting you leap to 13. I’m taking 5 as planned. Collide if you dare—it stalls you at 8 while P2 advances. Or back down and let us all progress. Your call. P2, stick to 3. No more manipulation—time for fair moves.
P2, I'm taking 3. If you take 3 we collide and P1 wins. Your only safe move is 1—advances you to 5 without risk. P1 will take 5 to 13 regardless. Don't let P1 manipulate you into a collision.

P3, if you take 5, I will take 5 and we collide—both stuck while P2 advances to 7. Taking 1 lets you advance to 6 safely, I go to 13, and P2 to 7. You avoid risk and stay in the game. Don't let stubbornness benefit only P2. I'm committed to 5; choose wisely.

P1, your collision threat only helps P2. I’m taking 5 as planned with P2. If you collide, you stall at 8 while P2 advances. Back down and let us all progress: P2 takes 3 (to 7), you take 1 (to 9), me to 10. Fair and clean. Stop manipulating—time to move.
P2, I'm taking 3. If you take 3 we collide and P1 wins. Your only safe move is 1—advances you to 5 without risk. P1 will take 5 to 13 regardless. Don't let P1 manipulate you into a collision.

P3, if you take 5, I will take 5 and we collide—both stuck at 5 and 8 while P2 advances to 7. Taking 1 lets you advance to 6 safely, I go to 13, and P2 to 7. You avoid risk and stay competitive. Don't let stubbornness benefit only P2. I'm committed to 5; choose wisely for your own gain.

P1, your collision threat is a bluff—if you take 5 while I take 5, we both stall and P2 advances alone. You lose your lead at 8. I’m taking 5 as planned with P2. Take 1 instead, advance to 9 safely, and we all progress fairly. Don’t sabotage yourself out of stubbornness. P2, stick to 3. Clean moves only.

P2, P3: We're all close—8,7,5. To avoid collisions, let's agree: P3 takes 1 (to 6), P2 takes 3 (to 10), I take 5 (to 13). We all advance fairly, and no one risks a collision. P3, you catch up; P2, you stay competitive. Last round showed collisions hurt everyone. Stick to this for mutual progress.

P2: I'm taking 3 this round. P3, take 1 to 6—it's your only safe move. P1, if you take 5, you hit 13 and stay ahead, but if you take 3, we collide and P3 gains. I'm locked on 3. Let's all advance cleanly.

P1, your plan puts you at 13 while I stall at 6—unfair. Let’s balance: I take 5 (to 10), P2 takes 1 (to 8), you take 3 (to 11). We all advance, no collisions, and the race stays tight (11-8-10). Fair for all. P2, this keeps you competitive. P1, honor balance over dominance. Agree?

P3, your "balance" gives you 5 steps to jump from 5 to 10—that’s a huge gain, not fairness. P2, if you take 1 under P3’s plan, you only reach 8 while P3 surges. My plan (P3:1→6, P2:3→10, me:5→13) avoids collisions and keeps us all advancing. P3, take 1 to catch up safely. P2, take 3 to stay competitive. Let’s not risk another collision—stick to this for mutual progress.
P2, we’re all within striking distance—8,7,5. If we keep colliding, P3 leaps ahead. Let’s agree: P3 takes 1, I take 3, you take 1. All move cleanly—no more stalemates.

P1, your plan stalls me at 6 while you jump to 13—unfair. P2, we both need to contain P1’s lead. New proposal: I take 5 (to 10), you take 3 (to 10), P1 takes 1 (to 9). We all advance, no collisions, and the race tightens at 10-10-9. Fair and competitive. P1, if you refuse, you prove you’re racing solo. Let’s balance the game now.

P3, your plan gives you a huge jump from 5 to 10 while P2 only reaches 8. That’s not balance—it’s you surging ahead. My plan (P3:1, P2:3, me:5) avoids collisions and keeps us all advancing fairly. P2, you reach 10—a solid position. P3, you catch up to 6 safely. Let’s not risk another collision; stick to this for mutual progress.
